Field.Value: Your estimate: [var=GAME_1_2A_AVERAGE_FACEBOOK_USE_SLIDER] hours per month. Unbiased!

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Turns out, the correct answer is 11 hours per month. Because your estimate was less than 11, it appears that you did not allow the 30 hour anchor that Terry suggested to pull your estimate away from the correct answer, even if the 30 hour anchor might have seemed relevant to your judgment. WAY TO GO!

The correct answer is 35 miles per hour. Because your estimate was greater than 35 mph, it appears that you were not biased by the 15 mph anchor. Perhaps you employed the bias mitigation strategy of [em2]adjusting[/em2] [em4]away[/em4] [em2]from your initial estimate. [/em2]Congratulations!!

Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
AMAZING!! The correct answer is 35 miles per hour. It would seem that you were not biased by the 15 mph anchor. Perhaps you employed the bias mitigation strategy of [em2]adjusting[/em2] [em4]away[/em4] [em2]from your initial estimate[/em2] to reach the correct answer!
Bottom line: don't be satisfied with the first answer that comes to mind! If you see an anchor, deliberately adjust away from it to avoid [em1]anchoring bias[/em1].
[FIREWORKS]

Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Turns out this particular sailboat is pretty fast, capable of sustained speeds of 35 miles per hour -- your answer was close. While most people might realize that the Gitana can go faster than 15 mph, they often don’t adjust far enough away from that anchor when judging the catamaran’s speed.
To avoid this common pitfall when making numerical judgments, remember: don't be satisfied with the first answer that comes to mind! [em2]If you see an anchor, deliberately adjust away from it to avoid[/em2] [em1]anchoring bias[/em1].

Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Turns out this particular sailboat is pretty fast, capable of sustained speeds of 35 miles per hour. While most people might realize that the Gitana can go faster than 15 mph, they often don’t adjust far enough away from that anchor when judging the catamaran’s speed.
To avoid this common pitfall when making numerical judgments, remember: don't be satisfied with the first answer that comes to mind! [em2]If you see an anchor, deliberately adjust away from it to avoid [/em2][em1]anchoring bias[/em1].

Field.Value:
Since Terry had suggested that Arthur had shady partners and seemed to do way better than the market on his stock picks, insider trading and money laundering might seem likely. But here's the key: [em2]the probability of two events occurring together is always lower than the probability of either event occurring individually[/em2], even if the two combined events seem more representative of the person or situation.
You avoided the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1] since you thought it was more likely that Flaherty was guilty of a single crime than two crimes together. Great job!! [FIREWORKS]

Can you think of why?

Field.Value:
Actually, your initial answer cited two kinds of crimes -- insider trading and money laundering -- which might have [em3]seemed[/em3] likely since Terry suggested that Arthur had shady partners and seemed to do way better than the market on his stock picks.
But here’s the key: [em2]the probability of two events occurring together is always lower than the probability of either event occurring individually[/em2], even if the two combined events seem more representative of the person or situation. To avoid the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1], remember that similarity does not trump pure probability.

Here's another (fictional) example. Wade Fleese is a wise-cracking, down-to-earth politico who's always ready for a beer and a chat with his constituents, who in turn elected him mayor by a solid margin. Mayor Fleese's popularity plunged, however, when an online video surfaced showing Fleese stumbling drunk from a bar and getting behind the wheel of his Buick. The Buick was later found neatly parked atop a fire hydrant outside his home. The local daily called for his resignation. Based on just this information, what is the most likely outcome:

Field.Value: Player's choice: "Mayor Fleese is convicted of drunk driving and resigns."

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Having the mayor convicted of drunk driving and resigning is a pretty compelling narrative, which certainly makes it seem more likely than either the conviction or resignation happening alone -- however, this misconception is a result of the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1].
By definition,[em2] both events happening together is less likely than either one of the two events happening alone[/em2], regardless of what [em3]seems[/em3] more likely.

Field.Value: Player's choice: "Mayor Fleese is convicted of drunk driving and stays in office."

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Having the mayor convicted of drunk driving and staying in office sounds like something a gregarious mayor might be able to get away with. However, believing that two events occurring together is more likely than either event happening alone -- just because it [em3]seems[/em3] more likely -- is a result of the [em1]conjunction fallacy[/em1].
By definition,[em2] both events happening together is less likely than either one of the two events happening alone. [/em2]

Field.Value: When you encounter a situation where you are using your attitudes, perceptions, beliefs, or feelings to make judgments about a random sample of people, there is always the risk of committing [em1]projection bias[/em1]. Here's what you can do to minimize the pitfalls of projection bias:

Field.Value:
Well -- this is a tough one... and it appears that your answer might have been impacted by the[em1] projection bias[/em1]. Many people who believe that the Government should limit the size of soft drinks in restaurants might overestimate the percentage of other people who agree with this point of view: only 31% of Americans.
Remember: when estimating the percentage of people who agree with your views, [em2]imagine ALL the people out there who hold a different opinion[/em2], and adjust your estimate accordingly. The percentage of people who agree with you is probably lower than you think!

Good job! Your estimate for the percentage of Americans who also believe that the Government should limit the size of soft drinks in restaurants was only slightly higher than the actual percentage -- 31% -- determined in a large national poll.
Remember, to avoid assuming a false consensus with your own opinion when assessing the views of others, [em2]imagine ALL of the people out there who hold a different opinion[/em2] and adjust your estimate accordingly to avoid[em1] projection bias[/em1]. The percentage of people who agree with you is probably lower than you think! [FIREWORKS]

Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
When you run into one of these challenges, [em2]try to avoid solely relying on your own feelings and attitudes to estimate how others feel[/em2]. Instead, try to put yourself into someone else's shoes -- someone quite different from yourself -- and imagine their perspective.
When are you most likely to be influenced by the [em1]projection bias[/em1]? In some cases, it may be when you have a strong opinion about an issue. Take global warming, for example -- many people (on both sides) feel very strongly about it. And when someone feels that their view is obviously correct, they may assume that many more people share it.

Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
There was a second case in which the [em1]representativeness heuristic[/em1] might influence your judgment in the game segment you just completed. This variety of bias resulting from the representativeness heuristic is called "[em1]base rate neglect[/em1]." When we commit base rate neglect, [em2]we neglect to think of how often an event occurs in general[/em2].
For example, do field goal kickers tend to make that field goal 9 times out of 10, or 1 time in 10? Instead, we tend to overemphasize the specific details of the instance we are considering -- like does the kicker seem nervous right now? Focusing on the player's nervousness on a particular day over and above the average performance of field goal kickers would be an example of the representativeness heuristic influencing your judgment.

Field.Value:
Nice job! Even though Mary may have seemed to resemble or "represent" the qualities of people who went to Entropy -- classy, cultured, stylish -- [em2]you paid attention to the base rate[/em2]. The clear majority of tenants ([em2]70%[/em2]) belong to Rocky's. In terms of probability, it's more likely that Mary will go there too.
When categorizing someone, in order to avoid [em1]base rate neglect[/em1], consider the probability or base rate of each category that person might belong to. [em2]Avoid only relying on the representativeness of the specific case [/em2]you are making a judgment about.
[FIREWORKS]

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Mary's description -- classy, cultured, stylish -- may have seemed to resemble or "represent" the qualities of people who go to Entropy. However, your answer might not have taken the base rates into account: [em2]70%[/em2] of the tenants belong to Rocky's, whereas only [em2]10%[/em2] go to Entropy. In terms of probability, these base rates provide strong evidence that it's more likely that Mary will go to Rocky's.
Just remember: in order to avoid [em1]base rate neglect[/em1] when categorizing a person or thing, consider the [em2]probability or base rate of each category that person might belong to[/em2], not just the representativeness of the specific case you are making a judgment about.

Field.Value: Your answer: It's more likely that Jennifer is a Satanist.

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Jennifer might resemble or "represent" what you think a Satanist would look like. But whenever you see the word "likely," it's a question of probability -- and remember, [em2]probability trumps similarity[/em2].
Less than 1% of Americans report being Satanists, whereas almost 80% of Americans report being Christians. So, unless Jennifer has a tattoo reading "I am a Satanist" on her forehead, there's a much higher probability that Jennifer is a Christian than a Satanist.

When you encounter a situation in which it's tempting to ignore base rates, as when the description of the specific person or event is particularly compelling, try the following:
Remember that you're dealing with a probability estimate. [em2]Try not to think too much about the specific case [/em2] (e.g., Mary's or Jennifer's qualities), but [em2]do think about base rates[/em2]. Sometimes base rate information is provided, like the way Mike told you information about the fitness facilities. Sometimes it's common sense, like knowing there are more Christians than Satanists in the U.S. If the specific case strongly resembles a particular category, you're at high risk of committing [em1]base rate neglect[/em1]!

Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value: First, [em2]remember why we feel this way[/em2]. It's natural to use our own opinion and experience as a place to start when trying to figure how other people think and feel. Also, we tend to surround ourselves with people who share our values and beliefs. This makes it even more likely that we will overestimate the percentage of people who shares our values and beliefs, because [em2]we see our views overly represented in others[/em2] around us.

Field.Value: Try to think about the opposite point of view -- might there be people who disagree with you? When estimating the percentage of people who agree with your opinion on an issue, try generating an initial estimate and then [em2]adjusting[/em2] [em4]downward[/em4] [em2]to account for all the people who disagree with you[/em2]. The percentage of people who agree with your opinion is probably lower than you think!

Mary, and Mike's description of her, is the specific case.

Field.Value: Your answer: The price tomorrow is more likely to go to 57.

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Your answer stated that the stock would go up the following day. Seeing that the stock's price had gone down over a period of days, perhaps you thought it was due for an up-tick.
This tendency, a belief that an outcome is due for a change, is a bias resulting from the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1]. Stocks, like roulette wheels, have a roughly equal chance of going up, going down or staying the same on any given day.

Field.Value: You thought that the stock had an equal chance of going up or down. In this response, you did not exhibit the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1]. Well done!! You didn't fall into the trap of thinking that, since the stock's price had gone down over a period of days, it was due for an up-tick, or that it would keep dropping. Stocks, like roulette wheels, have a roughly equal chance of going up, going down or staying the same on any given day. [FIREWORKS]

Field.Value: Your answer: The price tomorrow is more likely to go to 54.

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
You answered that the stock would close at 54 the following day. Seeing that the stock's price had gone down over a period of days, perhaps you thought it would continue its trend.
If you had thought the price trend was due for a change and would go up the next day, you would have committed the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1] -- which you didn’t, so great job! However, your answer that the stock would close at 54 the following day was not more likely than an outcome that had an equal chance of going up or down. Keep in mind that random events -- like stock prices on a given day -- have a roughly equal chance of going up, going down or staying the same.

Field.Value:
[RADIO] Think about this example:
Let's say you're standing at the door of a car factory that is continually producing silver and white cars in equal numbers over time. The cars are painted and completed in a totally random sequence -- you don't know which color car is rolling off the assembly line and out the door next.
While you're standing at the factory exit, you see the following sequence of cars roll out: silver, white, white, white, white. What color do you think the next car will be?

Field.Value: Not quite. Remember: the sequence of cars is [em2]totally random[/em2]. That means that whatever happened before will not affect what happens next. If I flip a coin and it comes up heads 10 times in a row, the next toss still has an equal chance of being heads or tails. It's just the way probability works. The fact that it [em3]feels[/em3] like it should come up tails doesn't matter.

[RADIO] Try this one:
You're in a hospital maternity waiting room with your friend who is pacing a track into the linoleum as he anxiously awaits the arrival of his first born child. He's rethinking the wisdom of keeping the baby's sex a "surprise." You know that the birth rate in this hospital is exactly even: 50% boys and 50% girls.
In the two hours you've been waiting, the ward nurses have come in six times to announce the arrival of a new baby. You and your friend have overheard the news. In every case, the nurses have announced the arrival of a girl. A moment later, a nurse comes out and finds your friend. Do you think she will report:

Your answer suggests that you might have thought that the streak of girls would continue. Remember the car factory? Equal chance of getting a silver car as a white car. Same thing here: equal chance of getting a boy as a girl.
When we're dealing with random events -- coin tosses, roulette spins, babies born, cars painted -- whatever happened last time, and the time before, and the time before that [em2]do not make any difference for the next outcome[/em2]. To avoid the [em1]gambler’s fallacy[/em1], remember: random is random!

When we're dealing with random events -- coin tosses, roulette spins, babies born, cars painted -- whatever happened last time, and the time before, and the time before that[em2] do not make any difference for the next outcome[/em2]. Field.Value:
I think you've really got it! Just remember: if an event is truly random, it doesn't matter how it's turned out previously. Flip a coin, roll a die, spin the wheel: [em2]what happened in the past will not affect what happens the next time[/em2].
When people feel like it's "due for a change," they’re exhibiting the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1]. Won't work in Vegas, either! [FIREWORKS]

Field.Value: Another kind of [em1]anchoring bias[/em1] that affects our everyday predictions is [em1]focalism[/em1]. Focalism occurs when we make a judgment about the impact of an event on something in the future, and [em2]neglect to consider and take into account all the other things[/em2] that will also influence the future event.

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Your answer indicates that you believe other people feel exactly the same as you do about hunting for sport. While many people attribute their own opinions to others when asked this type of question, rating others exactly the same as themselves may be a result of [em1]projection bias[/em1].
When you encounter a challenge that asks you to rank your attitudes or feelings about a topic, [em2]DO NOT assume that others share your view[/em2]. Revise your assessment of what others think or feel about a topic to be further away from your own opinion than you initially estimate.

When you encounter a challenge that asks you to rank your attitudes or feelings about a topic, [em2]DO NOT assume that others share your view[/em2]. Field.Value: This situation was designed to introduce you to a bias called the [em1]gambler's fallacy[/em1] that results from relying on the [em1]representativeness heuristic[/em1]. This type of representativeness heuristic involves not judgments about people or things, but about random sequences, such as coin flips. We often forget that random events can be independent.

Field.Hint: A description of what is going on during this dialogue.
Field.Title: Parenthetical

Field.Hint: A collection of audio files that should be played during this dialogue.
Field.Title: Audio Files

Field.Hint: A collection of image files that represent this dialogue.
Field.Title: Pictures

Field.Hint: A short description of what happens in this dialogue.
Field.Title: Description

Field.Hint: The actor who is talking.
Field.Title: Actor

Field.Hint: The actor who is listening.
Field.Title: Conversant

Field.Hint: The text that is displayd to the player in a list as a dialogue option.
Field.Title: Menu Text

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
If you've ever watched a roulette wheel at a casino, for example, and the ball lands on red 5 times in a row, you might think that it should land on black on the next spin -- but the chances of getting red or black on the next spin never change, and are always independent of what has come before. Same goes for coin flips -- assuming you're flipping a fair coin, whether you flipped heads 1 time or 10 in the past, it's just as likely to come up heads as it is likely to come up tails on the next flip: 50%. [em2]Believing that an outcome in a random sequence of independent events is due for a change is a result of the gambler’s fallacy.[/em2]
Interestingly, stock movements can also be considered random. Because the market adjusts almost immediately to any factors affecting stock price, it is almost impossible (without insider information) to predict whether a stock will go up, down, or stay the same on a [em3]given day[/em3]. A set of previous increases doesn't give a stock "momentum" that makes a future increase more likely, nor does it predict that it must go down.

[ENDCLIP]

Field.Value: Next, Barola asked you about the record length of a marlin. Do you remember how we talked about [em2]anchors -- values that can affect your numerical judgments[/em2] and the fact that they can come from a number of places such as your friends, your boss, or even your own personal knowledge? In this case, Barola provided you with an anchor -- the number 10. Even though the number 10 came from his question about the number of cities with populations larger than New York, so it was completely irrelevant to your estimate of the length of the longest marlin, this irrelevant anchor could still have influenced your judgment. In your case --

To avoid [em1]anchoring bias[/em1], keep in mind:
1. [em2]Be aware[/em2] that the information you just considered can influence subsequent judgments, whether it is relevant or not.
2. Don't passively accept your first guess. [em2]Make a deliberate adjustment AWAY from the anchor.[/em2] If you think the true value is higher than the anchor, revise your first estimate and go higher. If you think the true value is lower than the anchor, revise your first estimate and go lower. Bottom line: don't stop at your first guess! [em2]Consider additional information[/em2] that might be relevant to your estimate.

Field.Value: To avoid [em1]focalism[/em1] when making a judgment about how we might feel in a certain situation, [em2]keep in mind that a single event is unlikely to be the[/em2] [em4]only[/em4] [em2]factor determining a future state[/em2]. Lots of other things might influence it as well, and ignoring them may introduce focalism into your judgment.

[VIDEOCLIP - game.]
BAROLA Of course -- the sport isn't for everyone. I mean: live and let live, right? They are great and noble creatures -- do you think it's wrong to hunt animals for sport?
[ENDCLIP]

Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
You chose values to represent how you and the "average person" feel about hunting for sport. You had a scale of 1 to 7, where "1" meant you think it's completely wrong to hunt animals for sport, "4" meant you have no opinion on the issue, and "7" meant you think it's totally OK.
This was another [em1]projection bias[/em1] challenge. Once again, [em2]people are more likely to see traits in others that they see in themselves[/em2]. So, if you think hunting for sport is OK, projection bias would lead you to think that others feel the same way.

Field.Value:
Wow, that was some serious blogging. And nice shelf technique, by the way. You'll be happy to know that Arthur Flaherty, after losing his appeals, his friends and all the cash the Government could find, has gone away for a l-o-o-o-o-n-g time. He claims to have found religion -- and particular comfort in needle point. Travis got off with a light sentence but lost more than his liberty. Terry most definitely is NOT standing by her man.
As you may have already guessed, there were some additional bias challenges woven into the finale of your adventure. Let's see how you did.

Since you chose the pallet with 12 items on it, your answer might have been influenced by another version of the [em1]representativeness heuristic[/em1] -- [em1]sample size neglect[/em1].
A larger sample -- in this case, the lot of 98 statues -- is more likely to be representative of the overall distribution of pieces. [em2]In a small sample, there is often more variability than in a larger one.[/em2] Although the small pallet might be quicker to search, there was a greater likelihood that it contained an uneven distribution of the blue statues that you were looking for, and possibly none of the blue statues were in it at all! On the other hand, it is unlikely that there wouldn't be some in the big pile.

[RADIO] Try another one:
Goldilocks, after her early developmental experiences with bears, decided to open a retro-chic restaurant. One of the menu staples is porridge.
Through hard experience, she has learned that her customers are apt to complain about the temperature of the porridge, no matter [em3]what[/em3] temperature she makes it. Certainly, she can relate. She has worked out a compromise: at 180 degrees, 50% of the people will complain and 50% will say that it's..."just right."
On a quiet morning, she'll get about 6 guests in a 15 minute period. On a busy day, she'll get about 30. On which kind of day do you think she'll get [em2]more than 50%[/em2] of her customers complaining?

Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Hmmm... your answer might have been influenced by [em1]sample size neglect[/em1]. Let’s go over the logic of how to reach the correct answer.
The question was, "On which kind of day do you think Goldilocks will get [em2]more than 50%[/em2] of her customers complaining?" ... in other words, which sample is more likely [em4]not[/em4] to resemble the average?
Think about Goldilocks's 6 or so customers on a quiet day, 3 of which are usually grouchy. If she has just [em3]1 extra person[/em3] come in with a bad mood, her numbers (50% grumpy, 50% happy) get all messed up. On a busy day, 1 extra grumpy person in 30 really wouldn't move the needle. Bottom line: [em2]there's a much greater potential for unusual results in a smaller sample[/em2].

On a busy day, 1 extra grumpy person in 30 wouldn't really move the needle.
Bottom line: [em2]there's much greater potential for unusual results in a smaller sample[/em2]. [FIREWORKS]

[RADIO] Try one more:
Harry and David have been fishing Lake Tlawotuha for years -- usually catching nothing. This year, they are quite excited that the US Department of Fish and Wildlife has stocked the lake with Triploid and Kokanee trout. They are, however, unclear about how many of each the Government put in the lake.
After the first day of fishing, Harry has a catch of 5 fish (a personal best), but David has a whopping 18 fish. Harry caught 3 Triploid and 2 Kokanee trout: 60% and 40%, respectively. David caught 14 Kokanee and 4 Triploid: 78% and 22% in favor of the Kokanee.
What do you think is more likely that the Government did:

When you're looking at a statistic,[em2] the larger sample will always come closer to the average[/em2]. Smaller samples often have unusual quirks that throw off the numbers. Remember to go big!

Not exactly. In fact, you seem to have guessed that Arthur had fewer bullets in his gun when it was fully loaded than he appeared to have shot. Interesting. This kind of handgun -- the Glock 17 -- most commonly accepts a 17 round magazine.
The key to avoiding [em1]anchoring bias[/em1] is to [em2]try to be aware of the anchor and adjust away from it[/em2]. Seek out additional information to aid your decision-making process when possible, as well. Don't simply accept the first answer that comes to mind!

Field.Value: You thought that the lowest recorded human body temperature was [var=AAR3_BODY_TEMP] degrees. Unbiased!

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
Nicely done! The lowest recorded human body temperature with a full recovery was 55.4 degrees, involving a child drowning incident in Sweden in 2010. You may have considered the average human body temperature, 98.6 degrees, but that didn't anchor your answer -- great job avoiding [em1]anchoring bias[/em1]!
Just remember: the key to this kind of anchoring is to[em2] be aware of the anchor and adjust away from it[/em2]. [FIREWORKS]

Considering that the [em3]average[/em3] human body temperature is 98.6 degrees, it wouldn't make much sense for the lowest recorded human body temperature to be [em3]higher[/em3] than 98.6 degrees!

Field.Value:

The thing to remember about this kind of bias challenge is that you're not looking for the appearance of "randomness." Toss a coin 3 times and 3 heads in a row will not violate any law of chance. Statistically, your chances of actually [em3]finding[/em3] a figurine are much better if you examine the larger pile. When given a choice between a smaller and a larger sample, [em2]the larger sample will almost always be a better representation of the average[/em2].
We exhibit [em1]sample size neglect[/em1] when we overestimate the extent to which small samples will resemble much larger ones or are overly confident in the validity of our conclusions based on small samples.

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
The challenge was to estimate how many bullets were in Flaherty's handgun when it was fully loaded.
And, yes: this was another [em1]anchoring bias[/em1] challenge, like the time people spend on Facebook or the size of the biggest marlin. This one was a little different: the anchor came from you.
Most people might think of handguns that have 6 bullets, like the 19th century Colt revolvers. That knowledge then becomes a potential self-generated anchor that can bias your answer. As it turns out, a modern handgun like the Glock 17 accepts magazines of 17, 19, and 33 rounds. Let's see how you did.

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
This game situation was designed to highlight another bias that results from relying on the [em1]representativeness heuristic[/em1], the [em1]perception of randomness[/em1]: some outcomes seem like they are more random than others that are equally random.
We often expect random sequences to resemble a certain mental model of randomness -- to "look" random. We might think that some patterns look or "feel" random -- like an alternating pattern of conviction and acquittal -- and other patterns look or "feel" less random -- like a string of convictions and then an acquittal. [em2]People tend to think that random sequences have a lot of alternations, to a greater extent than you should actually expect for chance events.[/em2]

Field.Value: Here, take a look for yourself:

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value: These are all the possible sequences of coin tosses, and each of these sequences is equally likely, happening 1/8th of the time. But Sequences 1 and 8 look very non-random, and so, due to this bias, we expect them to be less common. Sequence 3, on the other hand, just looks more like a typical random sequence, and so it [em3]feels [/em3]like it should somehow be more likely to occur.

Field.Hint: The text that is spoken by the actor.
Field.Title: Dialogue Text
Field.Value:
[VIDEOCLIP - Closing video]
This concludes your adventure today, both with Terry and with these various forms of cognitive biases.
[A MOVING COLLAGE of the striking imagery...Jennifer, the Venn diagram, the examples, scenes from the game etc.]
Just remember:
We explored three kinds of biases today:
1. Anchoring: Think of additional information and consciously adjust away from the anchor. Don't get stuck on your first guess. 2. Representativeness: Keep in mind that similarity is not probability. The conjunction of two events is less likely than either one event. Larger samples tend to be more accurate than smaller samples, and are more informative than single cases. 3. Projection: Remember that we tend to overestimate how many other people share our beliefs, preferences, and feelings.
These biases are deeply ingrained in us -- but with knowledge and practice, we can avoid the pitfalls that they sometimes bring.
Thank you for playing!

Field.Value: In short, we may erroneously think that a pattern that looks or "feels" random is more likely to occur. However we may feel things should turn out, the truth is that, [em2]for any small sample, all patterns and outcomes are equally possible[/em2].
